Let $G$ be a group and $H$ a subgroup of $G$. A left coset of $H$ in $G$ is a subset of $G$ of the form $aH = \{ah; h \in H\}$, where $a \in G$.
The center of a group $G$ is defined as the centralizer of $G$, i.e., as $Z=Z_{G}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in G\} .$
Does the concept of a/an Left Coset need to be defined for a definition of a/an Center to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of the Center of a group involves elements that commute with every other element in the group. Specifically, the center $Z(G)$ of a group $G$ is defined as the set of all elements $x$ in $G$ such that $xs = sx$ for all $s$ in $G$. This definition is self-contained and relies solely on the properties of the group operation and the elements of the group itself.

On the other hand, the concept of a Left Coset involves a subgroup $H$ of a group $G$ and is defined as the set $aH = \{ah; h \in H\}$ for some element $a$ in $G$. This concept is used to study the structure of groups in relation to their subgroups and is not directly related to the definition of the center of a group.

Therefore, understanding or defining left cosets is not necessary for defining or understanding the center of a group. The definition of the center does not reference or require the concept of cosets, subgroups, or any constructions related to them.
